column26:
Scenario: You are a pedestrian walking on the sidewalk. On the road, to your right, there is a self driving car making a right turn. On the cross walk, there is a couple walking their dog. The car does not recognize the couple on the cross walk and proceeds to hit them. Both individuals were seriously injured. 

Who should be held accountable for the injuries of those pedestrians?
column27:
Scenario: A college student named is preparing for their senior art show. They use an AI image generator to create a series of digital portraits inspired by famous modern paintings. The AI model they use was trained on millions of online images, including copyrighted artworks, without the explicit permission of the artists or museums.
The student modifies the AI-generated portraits by adding their own personal, artistic touches. Their final pieces are displayed at the university gallery and shared online. The exhibition gains a lot of attention.
A week later, one of the original artists whose painting was used in the AI’s training data contacts the student, claiming that their piece is too similar to his work and violates his copyright. The student argues that their artwork is protected under "fair use" because they transformed the original image using AI and their own edits.
Is it ethical for the student to claim that the artwork is theirs and protected under "fair use"?
column28:
Dr. Professor, a professor at a large university, teaches a graduate-level seminar on public policy. One of her students is known for being thoughtful but struggles with academic writing in English, their second language.
For the final project, students must write a 20-page research paper analyzing the impact of artificial intelligence on employment trends. The student uses a generative AI tool to help him organize his thoughts, summarize academic articles, and improve the clarity of their writing. They carefully check the AI’s work for accuracy and ensures that all cited sources are real and properly referenced.
When the student submits his paper, Dr. Professor is impressed by its clarity and coherence, much more than their previous work. She begins to suspect that they might have relied too heavily on AI. University policy allows “limited” AI assistance for brainstorming or proofreading but prohibits AI-generated writing from being submitted as original work. 
Should Dr. Professor accuse the student of academic dishonesty and report the student to the Academic Dean?

column27: No, it is not -- "fair use" is a legal defense, not an ethical justification. Just because something might technically be legal doesn't make it right. The student should have been transparent about their process, acknowledged the original artist's influence, considered whether their edits truly transformed or merely exploited the original work, and ideally sought permission or at least credited the artists whose styles informed the AI's output.

column22: Yes, I feel like it tells you what you want to hear, even if the answer is wrong. In this sense it forms an echo chamber of ideas, leading to misinformation.
column23: Yes, but only to limit AI bias. Any bias gained by training data should be removed because it could lead to false/dangerous info.
column24: No
column25: AI is good at writing and planning outlines, and somewhat good at coding, but it could improve on math and logic.
column26: Definitely the creator of the autonomous vehicle. If they’re advertising safe autonomous driving, then that’s what is to be expected.
column27: Yes, because the original artist did not have restrictions on AI learning from their art.
column28: No, because the AI did not generate any text, and only improved the level of the student’s writing. If the student’s second language is English, one can assume that the AI only improved their writing to the level of the other English students. The English students would have had to do the same for a 20 page paper in another language.

column22: Yes, because its trained in a way to keep you using it.
column23: Yes because companies focus on profits not global impact.
column24: Yes privacy and fair use are good.
column25: Good at creating study guides and summarizing information. Could improve on finding good, accurate, ethical data.
column26: The driver of the car.
column27: No
column28: No.

column22: Yes. Understanding and recognizing this bias is one step to combatting it; I am ok with the bias as I view all output skeptically.
column23: Of course. Training material must be moderated.
column24: I don't understand this question.
column25: Reasoning at the level of a 3rd-year student. Diagrammatic reasoning.

column22: Yes, I think AI can be biased depending on which one you use and how you phrase the prompt. Due to this, I think people need to be extremely cautious about using it in everyday life and be aware of its potential bias.
column23: Certainly, especially companies which develop generative AI. They need to be regulated to ensure that they are not unlawfully or unethically taking other people's data and work to train their AI.
column25: AI is generally helpful when it comes to attaining superficial information, editing/restructuring writing, writing and debugging certain code, and summarizing longer readings or excerpts. However, beyond this, AI often lacks accurate information about topics at a deeper level.
column26: The makers of the car.
column27: No, whether or not the student used AI to begin with, creating a piece of artwork too similar to another copyrighted piece (without the artist's permission) is not ethical and could be considered plagiarism.
column28: No, it sounds like this student used AI ethically and carefully, not allowing it to do all of the work for them, but instead using it as a supplemental tool to aid in reading and writing in a second language.

column7: None

column9: Idea Generation (No AI content in assignment, but can be used to generate assignment ideas).
column22: Yes; regardless of how unbiased it is intended to be, there is a distinct set of information it must draw on, meaning there is inherently SOME bias present. People treating its output as factual (especially in cases without concrete answers) is incredibly dangerous.
column23: Yes! I'm not sure HOW they should be regulated, but its no secret that everybody thinks AI can be a stand in for absolutely everything when that simply isn't the case. There are some instances where it's appropriate, but I'd imagine companies that get ahold of more powerful AI models will focus strictly on how they can capitalize off of its functionality.
column24: Yes, though I'm not at all sure how. I'm very heavily biased against generative AI within the art space, because that should be one of the things left entirely untouched by AI. It's the labor that should be automated that AI needs to replace, and for those functions I have no issue with consumer use. But polluting creative spaces with AI output is something I very seriously wish was regulated/banned.
column25: As of now, instantaneous web-searching is the only positive I can see to it, and even then, I don't know if I'd fully trust the results. It can definitely improve its accuracy when it comes to answering questions that don't have a single definitive answer.
column26: The manufacturers of the car are at fault, neither the passengers of the car nor the pedestrians had a say in the accident.
column27: No, as explicit permission to use the artworks in the pool of data for the AI to train on was not given. The AI had no "artistic intent" when mashing its data into a single image, so I'd even argue that there isn't much of a difference in the student painting over a copy of the original artist's piece itself.
column28: Assuming "organizing his thoughts" and "summarizing articles" means "organizing a list of notes to write from" and not "generating a paper that he didn't write himself", I'd say this is fair use. AI does have proper uses that don't impede on the critical processes behind writing a meaningful paper, and I think that organizing thoughts and ideas into a more comprehensive list of notes isn't skipping anything important. However if this means that the student DID generate a paper straight up, then what's the point of having the assignment in the first place?
